Chapter 4, Part 4: Distinctions in the Four Eloquences, among the formless dharmas, the mind and mental factors have already been discussed, now we will next discuss the formations not associated with the mind.
Verse:
The formations not associated with the mind are attainment, non-attainment, homogeneity,
The two mindless samÄdhis, life, characteristics, name-body, etc.
Commentary:
Etc. refers to sentence-body, syllable-body, and the nature of combination.
Type shows the other dharmas that are conceived, which are the same as the previous types.

It is said that there are those who conceive that apart from attainment, etc., there is the nature of attainment, etc., of the aggregates. These dharmas are not associated with the mind, therefore they are called formations not associated with the mind, unlike the mental factors that arise together with the mind, sharing the same basis and object, and being associated with the mind.

The term mind is mentioned to show that attainment and so forth are types of mind, and that mental factors and their supports and objects are the same as mind and also types of mind. In order to distinguish them, it is said that they are not associated.
Unconditioned dharmas are also types of mind, but they have no support or object, so they are also not associated. In order to distinguish them, the term active is used again.
This has been generally indicated.
It should be further explained separately. Among them, the characteristics of attainment and non-attainment are discussed first.
A verse says:
Attainment refers to acquisition and accomplishment, non-attainment is the opposite of this.
Attainment and non-attainment only exist in one's own continuum and in the two cessations.
The treatise says:
Although the meanings of attainment, acquisition, and accomplishment are the same, they are explained with different names based on different aspects.
There are two kinds of attainment: that which was not attained before and that which was already attained before.
The attainment of that which was not attained before is called acquisition, and the attainment of that which was already attained is called accomplishment.
You should understand that nonacquisition is the opposite of this. That is, it is that which has not yet been acquired or that which has been lost after being acquired.

Nonacquisition that has not yet been acquired is called nonobtainment. Nonacquisition that has been lost is called nonaccomplishment. Therefore it is said that the nature of an ordinary person is called nonobtainment of the holy dharmas.
In what dharmas does acquisition and nonacquisition exist?

In the conditioned, acquisition and nonacquisition exist in oneâ€™s own life stream, not in the life streams of others or in nonliving things, because one can possess or not possess the aggregates that fall into oneâ€™s own life stream.
The aggregates in the life streams of others and the aggregates of nonliving things are definitely not possessed or not possessed.
In the unconditioned, only cessation resulting from discrimination and cessation not resulting from discrimination have acquisition and nonacquisition.
There is not a single sentient being who does not possess cessation not resulting from discrimination. Therefore the Abhidharma-nyÄyÃ¢nusÄra-Å›Ästra says:
Who possesses pure dharmas?

All sentient beings, except for the first moment of the holy path in the life stream of one bound by all bonds, and all others bound by all bonds, all other sentient beings possess cessation resulting from discrimination.
There is definitely no one who attains space, because there is no attainment of space;
nor is there anyone who does not attain it, because there is no non-attainment.
If a dharma can be attained, it can also be non-attained; if a dharma cannot be attained, it cannot be non-attained. This principle is certain.
Based on this attainment, the following statement is made:
The form aggregate and the formation aggregate are attained by one attainment, and the other aggregates and formations are also said to be the same.
Contaminated and uncontaminated dharmas are attained by one attainment, and conditioned and unconditioned dharmas are attained by one attainment. Such categories should be considered in the same way.
The author of the treatise asks this question here:
How do we know that there is a separate entity called attainment?
One should answer him as follows:
Because it is said in the scriptures.
As it is said in the scriptures, the Blessed One said:
One should know that such a person has attained wholesome dharmas and unwholesome dharmas.
If one says that the scriptures speak of a wheel-turning king who has attained the seven treasures, that is an error of excess.
This objection is not reasonable, because the king has unrestricted mastery over the seven treasures and is therefore said to possess them.
If you say that the same is true of the possession spoken of in other scriptures, this is not reasonable, because the present has mastery over the present alone, not over the past and future.

This means that the wheel-turning king has mastery over the present seven treasures, because they are dominant results and are always present, and he can make them turn as he wishes, and for that reason he is said to possess them.
But this is not so of good and bad dharmas.
When, for example, good dharmas are present, one can say that the pudgala possesses present good dharmas, but he must be further specified as to past and future bad dharmas.
If there is no present acquisition, by virtue of what other dharma can one speak of mastery?
The same is true of the present bad dharmas when good dharmas are present.
How much more so for those who hold that the past and future are totally devoid of substance? Over what can one speak of possession?

If you claim that one is said to be in possession of a dharma because it has the power to produce it in the future, this is also unreasonable, because this would lead to the absurd consequence that one would possess what is not desirable.
That is, ordinary beings in their final existence who are definitely going to produce pure dharmas would be holy beings.
Arhats in their final thought would definitely be unable to produce pure dharmas again and would not be arhats.

They would fall back and become ordinary beings. The passions that are to be eliminated by the path of insight of the mundane realm would never arise again and they would be the fruit of stream-enterer.
Also, if you admit that there is a separate thing called possession, what is unreasonable about that?
The reason is unreasonable, because the possession that you hold is not something that can be known as having substance,

like form, sound, etc., or greed, hatred, etc., nor is it something that can be known as having a function, like the eyes, ears, etc. Therefore, there is no such thing as a separate thing called possession.
To hold that there is a separate thing is unreasonable.
This is definitely not so, because it is not unreasonable.
This is because the possession that is admitted is the cause of not losing a dharma that has been acquired.
It is also the sign of the knowledge that this is bound to that.
Apart from this, what other great function is there that surpasses this, such that it is said to be non-existent?
If so, then what is the use of positing this attainment?
Only in the basis of support, where the seeds exist, not yet removed or damaged, and are able to grow freely, is the state of accomplishment established.
By this, one does not lose the dharmas already attained, and it is also the sign of the knowledge that this belongs to that.
What is this again?

Moreover, the good dharmas are roughly of two kinds:ğŸ”½The first is not attained through the cultivation of effort, and the second is attained only through the cultivation of effort, which are called innate and acquired.

As for those not attained through the cultivation of effort, if the seeds in the basis of support have not yet been damaged, it is called accomplishment. If the seeds in the basis of support have already been damaged, it is called non-accomplishment.

That is, when the roots of good are severed, the seeds of the roots of good in the support are damaged by the power of wrong views, and this is called severance. It is not said that the roots of good in the support are completely destroyed that are called severed.
That which must be cultivated by the power of effort is called possession if the dharma in the support has already arisen and the power of its birth is sovereign and not damaged.
The opposite of this is called nonpossession.
Bad and indeterminate dharmas are called nonpossession when their seeds are destroyed or subdued by the path of opposition or when there is no power to generate actual dharmas.
The opposite of this is called possession.
Therefore the possession that you affirm is useless.
Such various erroneous opinions are only empty words and have no real meaning.
What dharma do you take to be seeds?
That is, name and form have a power of transformation and evolution that is proximate to the production of their own fruits.
What is meant by name and form?
That is, the five aggregates.
How do you grasp this as the nature of seeds?
It is the cause for the arising of dharmas such as good.
Is it general or specific, and of the same kind as itself?

Moreover, what you grasp should be just that much. If you say it is general, the substance of the seeds should be provisional, and it is not reasonable for a provisional [dharma] to be the cause of a real [dharma].
If you say it is specific, how can you grasp the seeds of indeterminate form as the cause for the arising of good and bad dharmas?
If good dharmas arise immediately after bad dharmas, or vice versa, what is the seed?

O one who is loved by the gods, you do not understand the nature of seeds. Because of the differences in volition that arise together with the previous mind, there are differences in the abilities of the subsequent mind. The differences in abilities on the subsequent mind are called seeds. Due to this, the transformation of the continuity [of mind] gives rise to future fruits.

What is meant here is that in an unwholesome mind there is a special ability that is induced by good [karma] and is proximate, which serves as the seed. From this, good dharmas can arise without interval;
or in a good mind there is a special ability that is induced by unwholesomeness and is proximate, which serves as the seed. From this, unwholesome dharmas can arise without interval.
Now, the special ability and seed that you hold, are they separate from that good or unwholesome mind, or are they not separate?
If they are not separate, wouldn't you admit that good [karma] is the seed of unwholesomeness, and unwholesomeness is the seed of good [karma]?
Who would hold that heat and fire have no separate substance, yet still say that only heat can burn and fire cannot burn?
How can it produce the ripening effect of the hells and other [realms]?
In an unwholesome mind, it places the special ability that is induced by the distinction of wholesome volition that can produce a desirable ripening effect, which serves as the seed.
How can it produce the retribution of a slave and so on?
In a pure good mind, it places the seeds of the power of the differences of the evil volition that attracts non-love retribution.

Because impure good minds are incapable of attracting the fruits of retribution that are loved, and pure good minds are incapable of attracting the fruits of retribution that are not loved, how can it be said that the two can attract two kinds of fruits?
In this way, you slander the ten powers of the Buddha, the World-Honored One, and the power of knowledge of what is possible and what is not.

Also, you should admit that the power of the differences of volition that attracts the differences of seeds is the same as the mind in having one fruit. Then, even in a pure mind, there would be the differences of power of impurity, and then a pure mind would also be able to attract the fruits of the three realms of existence.

Because it is also admitted that pure minds also place the seeds of afflictions, then pure minds would also be able to act as the cause for the arising of afflictions. Or, in the body of an arhat, the afflictions eliminated by the path of cultivation would arise without seeds.

Because it is admitted that pure seeds are placed in a mind that is defiled, then a defiled mind would be able to act as a cause for the arising of a pure mind. Or, a pure mind that arises subsequent to a defiled mind in the body of an Ärya would be devoid of seeds and would not be born, or at that time it would be called the first pure mind.

Also, because the nature of an arhat who is subject to falling away may retrogress and generate various passions, then the three realms of seeds of the passions must exist in the mind of an arhat who is a post-learner.
We will discuss later the retrogressing of the passions.
Also, we have never seen a case in which dharmas of different kinds have different natures but are devoid of separate substances. Therefore the above theories are extremely confused and erroneous.

Also, how can the differences in the volition that existed previously and the differences in the power of the subsequent mind be considered cause and effect and be in a relationship of correspondence?
What is there to doubt about this?
The principle of cause and effect is such that only because there are differences in volition existing previously can there be differences in the power of the subsequent mind.
If there were no differences in prior volition, then differences in the power of subsequent minds would not occur.
Therefore, these two can have cause and effect and mutually correspond.
If there were something produced when there is volition, then this meaning would be possible;
but when there is volition, nothing is produced at all, because the future does not exist.
Prior volition and subsequent mind do not exist simultaneously. How can it be said that they correspond as cause and effect?
Such meanings will be further examined in the discussion of the past and future.
As for what they say, that the seeds of wholesome roots in the non-support are not ultimately harmed, and that is called severed, why do they only say that they are not ultimately harmed?
They should only say that they are ultimately not harmed, because they originally have no seeds.
Moreover, what they say contradicts the sutras, because the sutras say that they are ultimately severed.
As the World-Honored One said:
One should know that such a person's wholesome dharmas are hidden and submerged, and unwholesome dharmas appear, but there are still wholesome roots that accompany them and have not been severed.
Because they have not been eliminated, there is still a possibility that the remaining roots of good can arise from these roots of good. Later, all of them are eliminated.
How is it that all of the weak roots of good are eliminated and not ultimately destroyed?
Therefore, they should only say that they are possessed by demons and speak this way by themselves.
Also, if the power of wrong views damages the function of the seeds of good and prevents them from producing sprouts, even if they are not ultimately eliminated, what use are they?
Because they are useless in producing sprouts of good roots.
If the power of wrong views cannot damage their ability to produce sprouts of good, then they should not be called severed roots of good, because they are able to produce good.

Also, when they say that one cultivates and obtains through the power of effort, if a dharma has already arisen in the basis, they say that one is said to be provided with the power of effort to produce it, and that this power is not damaged. This is also unreasonable, because in their system there is no such thing as the arising of good dharmas, much less the arising of dharmas in the body, the power of producing which is not damaged.
As previously explained, their system has no future, so where is there a power of effort?
Because the principle of the cause of its arising does not exist, one should not seek for another cause of non-arising.
Since there is no cause of arising, on what basis do they say that the power of arising is not damaged?
This refutes the theory of the VaibhÄá¹£ikas that the various categories of the elimination of the passions are real things.

However, they say that just as seeds are burned by fire and transformed into something else that is incapable of producing, in the same way, the passions are incapable of arising in the body of an Ärya, and this is called the elimination of the passions. The worldly path damages the seeds of the passions in the basis and this is also called elimination.

The opposite of the above is called not yet eliminated. This should now be explained. What is the difference between eliminating the various passions by the mundane path and eliminating the various passions by the supramundane path?
Both are like seeds, because they are burned by fire and are incapable of producing sprouts.

If it is said that like seeds, they are not extremely damaged and are able to permanently produce sprouts, etc., then the elimination of the seeds of passions by the mundane path is also like this. They are still able to produce the results of various activities as before and are able to give rise to various passions. How can it be said that they are like seeds that are damaged?
Seeds that are damaged are said to be unable to produce sprouts. If they are able to produce sprouts, they are not called damaged.

The elimination of passions by the worldly path is also like this. If the seeds of passions are damaged, they should be unable to produce. Since they are able to produce later, they should not be called damaged. If they are not called damaged, how can they be called eliminated?
Moreover, in a single moment of thought, the eliminator and the eliminated cannot exist together. The meaning of elimination is not established.
Therefore, what they say, namely, that name-and-form has a proximate power to produce its own effect, is called a seed, is not established.
Also, what they say, namely, that this is due to the transformation of the continuity, what is called transformation?
It is the difference in nature between the prior and subsequent states within a continuity.
What is called continuity?
It is the dharmas of the three time periods that have the nature of cause and effect.
What is called difference?
It is the power to produce an effect without interruption.
Thus, Venerable One!
All that is said has a different meaning and different words, and its head is also different.

Because the metaphysician has no continuity with a difference in nature between prior and subsequent states, nor are there the dharmas of the three time periods that have the nature of cause and effect, nor is there the power to produce an effect without interruption, as will be explained later.

They, due to their aversion to the meaning of the Dharma, give rise to various faults within the holy teachings, just as the many faults that are contrary to reason are given rise to within the holy teachings by slandering attainment.
If you admit that possession really exists, what contradiction does this involve in the meaning of the holy teachings?
Even though the author of the ÅšÄstra has said many things in accordance with his own opinions, he has accomplished nothing, because the seeds that he accepts are unreasonable.
Since seeds do not really exist, we know that what you accept as possession is the cause of nonloss of dharmas already obtained.
It is also the sign of the knowledge that these dharmas are bound to that person.
We know that it has a function, and since its function exists, we know that it has a separate substance.
Therefore the substance and function of possession are completely established.
In the place where the Abhidharma masters discuss their doctrines, the logicians often set forth their own opinions about the seeds of dharmas and confuse the correct interpretation.
There are also masters who, in the place of seeds, establish different names according to the meaning, such as following realm, perfuming, power, nonloss, and increase.
Therefore, I extensively engage in analysis here, destroying their assertions and establishing the correct doctrine.
Thus, the nature of acquisition and non-acquisition has been established. The meaning of their distinctions should now be extensively considered.
First, what is acquisition?
Verse:
The dharmas of the three times each have three [types of acquisition]. The wholesome, etc. are only wholesome, etc.
The acquired with attachment belongs to its own realm. The acquired without attachment extends to the four [realms].
The non-learner and non-non-learner have three [types of acquisition]. The non-eliminated has two types.
Commentary:

The acquisitions of dharmas of the three times each have three types. That is to say, past dharmas have past acquisitions, future acquisitions, and present acquisitions. Future and present dharmas each have three acquisitions.
This is said based on the meaning of possibility. The distinctions within will be further discussed later.

Moreover, the acquisitions of wholesome, etc. dharmas are only wholesome, etc. That is to say, wholesome, unwholesome, and indeterminate dharmas have wholesome, unwholesome, and indeterminate acquisitions, respectively.

Also, the acquisition of dharmas that are bound to a realm is only of that realm. That is, dharmas of the desire, form, and formless realms have only the three acquisitions of desire, form, and formless, respectively.
If dharmas are not bound to a realm, their acquisition is of four kinds. That is, dharmas that are not bound to a realm are of four kinds in general, namely, bound to the three realms and not bound.
If distinguished individually, the acquisition of cessation not due to deliberation is bound to the three realms.
If the acquisition of cessation due to deliberation is bound to the form and formless realms and is not bound.
The acquisition of the truth of the path is only not bound.

Also, the acquisition of dharmas that are learners is only of learners. If dharmas are post-learners, their acquisition is only of post-learners. Therefore, the acquisition of learner and post-learner dharmas is each of one kind.
The acquisition of dharmas that are neither learners nor post-learners is generally of three kinds.
If distinguished individually, the five aggregates that are grasped and the three unconditioned dharmas are generally called dharmas that are neither learners nor post-learners.
The five aggregates subject to clinging and non-analytical cessation are not realized by the noble path, and only have the attainment of neither learner nor post-learner.
If the cessation realized by the learner's path, the attainment is only of the learner.
If the cessation realized by the post-learner's path, the attainment is only of the post-learner.
Also, the dharmas to be eliminated by insight and cultivation are eliminated by insight and cultivation, respectively.
The dharmas not to be eliminated have two kinds of attainment in general.
Distinguishing them individually, the pure dharmas are called not to be eliminated.
If non-analytical cessation and cessation realized by the non-noble path, the attainment is only of one kind, namely, eliminated by cultivation.
If cessation realized by the noble path and the truth of the path, the attainment is only of one kind, namely, not to be eliminated.
It was said earlier that each of the three time periods has three kinds of attainment. Are all conditioned dharmas definitely so?
No, it is not so.
How is it?
The verse says:
The attainment of the unconditioned arises simultaneously, excluding the two, supernormal powers, and transformations.
The obtainment of the two mindless meditative attainments and the two mindless states of composure is simultaneous with the mind.
The treatise says:
The obtainment of the unobscured-non-defiled is only simultaneous, without arising before or after, because its power is weak.
Is the obtainment of all unobscured-non-defiled dharmas definitely so?
No, it is not so.
How is it?

Excluding the two supernormal powers of the eye and ear, and that which can transform, that is, the supernormal powers of the eye and ear, and the mind that can transform, because their power is strong and they are accomplished by the distinctions of added effort, although they are included in the unobscured-non-defiled nature, they have obtainment that arises before, after, and simultaneously.ğŸ”½Moreover, the obtainment of the four aggregates of the path of deportment is mostly cut off in the world and cut off in a moment, excluding the Buddhas, the bhiká¹£us AÅ›vajit, and others who are well-practiced in the path of deportment.

If the obtainment of the four aggregates of the realm of craftsmanship is also mostly cut off in the world and cut off in a moment, excluding the celestial spirit ViÅ›vakarman and others who are well-practiced in the realm of craftsmanship.
Are only the acquisitions of non-obscured-non-defined dharmas simultaneous?
No, it is not so.
How is it?

The acquisitions of obscured-non-defined form are also like this. That is to say, only the bodily and verbal manifest actions of defilement in the first meditation of the form realm are also as before, only having simultaneous arising. Although they are of the highest level of defilement, they are also unable to give rise to unmanifest actions, therefore their power is weak and inferior. Because of this, there are no dharmas with acquisitions before or after.
Are the acquisitions of all form in the desire realm also definitely only simultaneous?
No, it is not so.ğŸ”½
How is it?
That is to say, the acquisitions of wholesome and unwholesome form belonging to the desire realm do not arise before, only having simultaneous arising and subsequent arising acquisitions.
Thus the characteristics of acquisition have been explained.
What are the characteristics of non-acquisition?
Verse:
Non-acquisition is pure and non-defined, each of the past and future has three,
The three realms and unattached to the three, the non-acquisition of the noble path,
Is called the nature of ordinary beings, it is relinquished by obtaining the dharma and changing stages.
Treatise:
As for the distinction of nature, all non-acquisitions are categorized as only non-defiled and indeterminate natures.

As for the distinction of time period, past and future [dharmas] each have three kinds of non-acquisitions, i.e., past dharmas and future dharmas each have three time periods of non-acquisitions. If present dharmas only have past and future non-acquisitions, there definitely are no present non-acquisitions, because present dharmas do not coexist with non-acquisition.
Some say:
Present dharmas have no present non-acquisitions, because of the contradiction in nature.

As for the distinction of realm, dharmas belonging to the three realms and unconditioned dharmas each have three kinds of non-acquisitions. Dharmas belonging to the desire realm have two realms of non-acquisitions, and those belonging to the form and formless realms and unconditioned dharmas are also like this.
There definitely are no non-acquisitions that are pure.
Why is this?
Because it is accepted that the non-acquisition of the noble path is called the nature of an ordinary being. As a treatise says:
What is the nature of an ordinary being?
It is the non-attainment of the teachings of the noble ones.
Non-acquisition is a synonym for non-obtainment.
How can pure dharmas be called the nature of an ordinary being, and what is non-obtainment?
What holy dharma is called the nature of an ordinary being?
Is it the non-obtainment of all holy dharmas in general, or is it only the non-obtainment of the receptivity to the knowledge of the dharma of suffering?
Some say:
It is the non-obtainment of all holy dharmas.
If that is so, wouldn't there be no ordinary beings, because no one would generally attain all holy dharmas?
If there is non-obtainment that is not mixed with obtainment, that is the nature of an ordinary being. If obtainment is mixed, it is not the nature of an ordinary being. Therefore there is no fault.
If that is so, the original treatise should say pure.

It is not so. The meaning of mixed is seen to exist. It is like saying this class of beings eats water and eats wind. Although there is no word pure, it is also known that they only eat water and wind, because they are not mixed with anything else.
Some say:

It is the non-obtainment of the receptivity to the knowledge of the dharma of suffering. However, after abandoning it, one does not again become an ordinary being, because one has already permanently destroyed its non-obtainment.
The author of the treatise further says this:
The state of distinction in the continuity of one who has not yet produced the noble dharmas is called the nature of an ordinary being.
Why does the author of the treatise further say this, namely, that the nature of an ordinary being is completely devoid of real substance?
If that is so, then what is the continuity of that state?
It refers to the continuity of the state of the eye, ear, etc.

Can it be that the state of the eye, etc. in a single moment is not the nature of an ordinary being, and yet it is said that the continuity of the eye, etc. is precisely the nature of an ordinary being?
It cannot be that a single moment can be called a continuity, because then there would be the fault of a moment having a non-real nature.
This is not only a case of the words contradicting the meaning, there is also another contradiction with the scriptures.
Therefore the World-Honored One said:
Thus it is called the one who follows faith entering the correct nature and leaving birth, transcending the stage of an ordinary being.
This stage of an ordinary being is precisely the nature of an ordinary being.
Why is this known?
Because it is said to be obtained and abandoned.
It is not that at that time one can be said to lose a part of the eyes and other faculties that one has already obtained.

When the holy one who has attained the holy Dharma is in the state of the path of insight, he possesses eyes and other faculties of all kinds, just as in the previous state and without any deficiency.

If the nature of the ordinary man has no separate substance, then it contradicts this scripture, because at that time there is no separate substance of the stage of the ordinary man that can be transcended.
If you claim that the evil destinies are the stage of the ordinary man, then one who has attained forbearance should not be an ordinary man.

If you claim that because the eyes, etc., are apart from the holy Dharma when one has not yet attained the holy Dharma, the name and concept of the ordinary man are provisionally established on the basis of them, and that when one enters the path of insight one transcends them, therefore it is said that one transcends the stage of the ordinary man, this is also unreasonable. How can it be said that at that time the eyes, etc., are transcended, when the dharmas of the eyes, etc., are as they were before and continue to exist?

If you say that the arhat who realizes the fruit of arhatship by the instantaneous type transcends the eye, etc., this is not so, because at that time he realizes the severing of the bonds of the eye, etc., and although he possesses the eye, etc., he is still said to transcend the bonds.
But in the present case, the eye, etc., are as they were originally, with bonds, and therefore the analogy is not apt.
If you say that the saint who has not yet eliminated desire transcends evil destinies, this is not so, because he has already obtained nonanalytical cessation with regard to them.

The saint who has not yet eliminated desire does not act, go, or proceed with regard to them, and for that reason he is said to transcend them. But what eye, etc., does the saint on the path of insight transcend?

If you say that there must be a dharma apart from the pot, etc., that is the nature of the pot, etc., this is not so, because the principle of abandoning the nature of the pot, etc., by breaking the pot, etc., is not established.
When the pure mind arises, the eye, etc., are as they were originally, and one abandons the nature of the ordinary person. Therefore, the analogy is not apt.
This also refutes the analogy of the nature of arising, etc.

If you say that the nature of the brÄhmaá¹‡a, etc., is not so, then just as there is a definite difference between the noble and the ordinary, because they are not seen to be the same, that is, each has a part that does not do or go, and a part that does do or go, with a definite difference,

there is not the slightest difference in wisdom, skill, restraint, or ability among the various classes of brÄhmaá¹‡a, etc., such that only one is able to do something and the others are not able to do it, and one can therefore maintain that there is a nature of brÄhmaá¹‡a, etc.

Although one also sees a slight difference between the central and border regions, etc., there is no separate nature, because it is admitted that there is a separate dharma called homogeneity that serves as the basis for the differences, so there is no error.
Isn't it just the noble dharmas that are called the nature of the noble? Because one accomplishes this nature, one is called a noble one.
In the same way, the dharmas of the ordinary person should be the nature of the ordinary person, and because one accomplishes this nature, one is called an ordinary person.
This example is not correct, because the noble dharmas are only possessed by the noble ones, so the noble dharmas can be said to be the nature of the noble.
How can it be established as the nature of an ordinary being?
If the dharma of an ordinary being only exists in an ordinary being and is universal to all ordinary beings, it can be the nature of an ordinary being.
Evil destinies, non-perception, and the northern continent Kuru are not universal to all ordinary beings, so they are not the nature of an ordinary being.
Other things such as the life faculty, although universal to all ordinary beings, do not only exist in ordinary beings, and are also not the nature of an ordinary being.
Moreover, only that which exists in ordinary beings and is universal to the continuum of ordinary beings, and is contrary to the attainment of the noble path, is the nature of an ordinary being.

Moreover, if there is a dharma that acts as the cause for the birth of the body of all ordinary beings, it is the nature of an ordinary being. Wouldn't karma and afflictions act as the cause for the birth of the body of all ordinary beings? What use is there for the nature of an ordinary being?

This criticism is unreasonable, because it is seen that a dharma can only act as the cause for another dharma by relying on other causes. The eye and so forth that are produced by karma and afflictions cannot be obtained apart from the four great elements, therefore there is a separate dharma called the nature of an ordinary being.
Therefore, it is called transcending the stage of ordinary beings.
Only by making this explanation can it be shown that the sutras spoken by the World-Honored One have great meaning.
The subsidiary discussion is now complete. We should further consider:
When are these non-acquisitions abandoned?
The non-acquisition of this dharma is abandoned when one acquires this dharma or changes to another stage.
Just as the non-acquisition of the holy dharmas is called the nature of an ordinary being, when one acquires the holy dharmas, one abandons the non-acquisition of the three realms.

In the same way, when one abides in the first undefiled mind, and so on, up to when one abides in the vajra-like samadhi, one abandons the non-acquisition of an arhat, as appropriate, when one acquires this dharma and abandons its non-acquisition. In this way, up to the fruit of arhatship.
When a temporarily liberated arhat acquires the non-acquisition of an arhat who is liberated independent of time, he abandons this non-acquisition.
The non-acquisition of other dharmas should be considered in the same way.
Moreover, if non-possession is called abandonment,
then when the possession of non-possession is severed and the non-possession of non-possession arises, this is called the abandonment of non-possession.
Although possession and non-possession each have other possessions and non-possessions, it is not an infinite regress.

By the power of possession, the original dharma and the possession of possession are accomplished. The power of the possession of possession accomplishes the possession of the dharma. How can it be an infinite regress?
The non-possession should also be examined in the same way. The non-possession of non-possession definitely does not arise together.

Moreover, when one is born from a lower realm to a higher realm, all the non-possessions of the lower realm are abandoned. When one is born from a higher realm to a lower realm, it should be understood in the same way. Because the non-possession changes due to the power of the basis.
Thus the characteristics of possession and non-possession have been explained.
What is homogeneity?
The verse says:

The treatise says:
There is a separate real entity called homogeneity. It refers to the mutual similarity of sentient beings. The Abhidharma Treatise calls it the same group.
The cause of the similarity of form, faculties, actions, food, etc., of sentient beings born in the same realm, and the cause of their mutual affection, is called homogeneity.
Because pure form, action, mind, and the four great elements are all its causes, form, etc.,
are not only the result of action. It is seen that form is the result of action that attracts a similar result, because faculties, actions, food, etc., are different.

If you say that the differences are due to the differences in the action that perfects the faculties, etc., this is not so. Or, there is form that is produced only by action that attracts a similar result, because homogeneity is different and faculties, etc., are different.
If form, etc., are only results of action, then the various actions, faculties, etc., that one desires to have or to be rid of should not exist.
Form, faculties, actions, and desires are similar to each other in this body, and therefore it is called homogeneity.

In terms of distinctions of realm, destination, rebirth, body, etc., there are innumerable kinds of similarities of sentient beings.

There is also similarity of dharmas, which means that in terms of aggregates, sense bases, and sense fields, the similarity of ordinary beings is abandoned when one enters the state of having left the ordinary, and the similarity of sentient beings is abandoned when one enters nirvana.

That is to say, the cause of the similarity of form, activity, enjoyment, and desire of those beings is called similarity.

When one enters the state of having left the ordinary, one abandons and attains similarities, and abandons the nature of an ordinary being without attaining it.
How do we know that the homogeneous character is not form?
Because it has a function that produces without a separate class of things. We know that it exists because we see its effect.
Just as we know that there was a previous action that produced the present effect.
Also, because the practitioner directly perceives it.
Why not admit that there is a homogeneous character of insentient things?

You also admit that there are destinies of humans and gods, and births in the womb and eggs, etc. Why not also admit that there are destinies of mango trees, etc., and births in mung beans, etc.?

One should only consider why the World-Honored One only speaks of the existence of the homogeneous character in sentient beings, and not in grasses and trees, etc.
Also, how do we know that such a homogeneous character exists as a real entity?

I understand it like this: because grasses and trees, etc. do not have mutual activity, desires, or mutual similarity, the separate existence of a homogeneous character is not mentioned in regard to them.
Also, because grass, etc., must be born only when sentient beings exist, only sentient beings are said to have similar attributes.
Also, this dharma is born from previous karma and present effort, but both of these are absent in grass, etc., therefore there are no similar attributes.
By this very fact, it is proven that there is a real entity.
Also, although there is similarity in color and shape between a wooden or painted image and its real form, it is said that only one is real.

Therefore, it is not that merely seeing similarity in them is called reality. One must only give rise to the word real with regard to similar and differentiated things. Therefore, we know that there is a real dharma of differentiation.
This word real arises from this dharma.
Also, because it was said before.
What was said before?
It was said that seeing the body and form is the result attracted by similar karma, because the faculties, functions, food, etc., are differentiated.
How is it that there is no further similarity in them that would give rise to the cognition and designation of non-difference?
Because the similarities are the cause of the similarity of events of the same type. They are the cause for the cognition and designation of mutual similarity of events of the same type.

Just as the eye, ear, etc. become the nature of form only when they are created by the primary elements, and although the primary elements are not created by other primary elements, the nature of form is still established.

What is the state of non-perception?
A verse says:

Its retribution is in the heaven of vast fruit.
The treatise says:
If one is born in the heaven of non-perceiving sentient beings, there is a dharma that causes the cessation of mind and mental factors, called non-perception.
This is a real entity that can block future mind and mental factors, causing them to temporarily not arise, like a dam blocking a river.

This dharma is entirely retribution for the attainment of non-perception, because in the heaven of non-perceiving sentient beings, non-perception and form are only retribution for the attainment of non-perception.

This attainment has no power to attract the continuity of aggregates or the life faculty, because the continuity of aggregates and the life faculty are only the results attracted by the fourth meditation with mind.

The other aggregates in that realm are common retribution, because in the heaven of non-perceiving sentient beings, before entering non-perception and after emerging from non-perception, there is mind for many periods of time.
However, because the state without mind is extremely long, it is generally called the heaven of non-perception.
In what place do sentient beings without perception dwell?
They dwell in the heaven of great fruit.
That is, within the heaven of great fruit there is a superior place like the intermediate concentration, called the heaven of non-perception.

They take past karma, etc., as the immediately antecedent condition to sustain them as food. That is, due to past karma attracting the homogeneous character of sentient beings and the faculty of life, and due to the mind of rebirth and the mind of the fruit of non-perception entering immediately without interval pulling and assisting, therefore they also have past contact, etc., as food to sustain them.
In the state without mind, there is only past contact, etc., as food, and none in the present at all.
In the state with mind, both kinds exist together. Those sentient beings, due to the arising of thought,

fall from that place. Having fallen, they definitely take rebirth in the desire realm, not in other places, because the power of the lifespan attracted by the practice of concentration cultivated previously is exhausted, and because they are unable to cultivate concentration again there, just as an arrow shot into the air falls when its power is exhausted.
If sentient beings are to be born in that place, they must have karma of the desire realm that will produce results in a later life.
It is like those who are to be born in the Uttarakuru continent, who must definitely have karma that will produce rebirth in the heavens.
The discussion of the mindless state is complete.
What are the two meditative attainments?

What are the characteristics of the first attainment of non-perception?
A verse says:

The treatise says:
As explained above, there is a dharma that can cause the cessation of mind and mental factors, called the mindless state.
Similarly, there is another dharma that can cause the cessation of mind and mental factors, called the attainment of non-perception.

The word thus only shows that this meditative attainment causes the cessation of mind and mental factors to be the same as the mindless state. Because it is accomplished or perfectly accomplished, it is called a meditative attainment.
Some other masters say:

The samÄdhi of nonconceptualization is either the samÄdhi of nonconceptualization or the nonconceptualization of the samÄdhi, and is called the samÄdhi of nonconceptualization because one produces this samÄdhi through disgust with and destruction of conceptualization.
Ordinary beings are unable to be disgusted with and destroy feeling, because they enter the samÄdhi while attached to feeling.

The treatise says:
Like the previous attainment of non-perception, the attainment of cessation is also like this.
That is, when one has already abandoned craving for the third trance state, there is a dharma that can cause the cessation of mind and mental factors, called the attainment of non-perception.
Similarly, when one has already abandoned craving for the sphere of nothingness, there is a dharma that can cause the cessation of mind and mental factors, called the attainment of cessation.

The difference between these two attainments is that the previous attainment of non-perception seeks liberation and is disgusted with conceptualization, and one enters it by first directing one's attention to the thought of liberation from conceptualization.
Now, the attainment of cessation seeks to abide in stillness and is disgusted with distraction, and one enters it by first directing one's attention to the thought of cessation of distraction.

Because the body one receives by being born in the sphere of neither conceptualization nor non-conceptualization is attracted by the most superior karma, it is called the summit of existence.
